questions.text: Extracellular fluid in adults differs from intracellular fluid in that its:

options.text: Volume is greater.
Tonicity is lower.
Anions are mainly inorganic.
Sodium: potassium molar ratio is higher.

questions.text: Blood group antigens (agglutinogens) are:

options.text: Carried on the haemoglobin molecule.
Beta globulins.
Equally immunogenic.
Inherited as recessive Mendelian characteristics.

questions.text: Total body water, expressed as a percentage of body weight:

options.text: Can be measured with an indicator dilution technique using deuterium oxide.
Is smaller on average in women than in men.
Rises following injection of posterior pituitary extracts.
Falls during starvation.

questions.text: Breakdown of erythrocytes in the body:

options.text: Occurs when they are 6–8 weeks old.
Takes place in the reticulo-endothelial system.
Yields iron, most of which is excreted in the urine.
Is required for the synthesis of bile salts.

questions.text: A person with group A blood:

options.text: Has anti-B antibody in the plasma.
May have the genotype AB.
May have a parent with group O blood.
May have children with group A or group O blood only.

questions.text: Blood platelets assist in arresting bleeding by:

options.text: Releasing factors promoting blood clotting.
Adhering together to form plugs when exposed to collagen.
Liberating high concentrations of calcium.
Releasing factors causing vasoconstriction.

questions.text: Plasma bilirubin:

options.text: Is a steroid pigment.
Is converted to Biliverdin in the liver.
Does not normally cross cerebral capillary walls.
Is freely filtered in the renal glomerulus.

questions.text: Monocytes:

options.text: Originate from precursor cells in lymph nodes.
Can increase in number when their parent cells are stimulated by factors released from activated lymphocytes.
Unlike granulocytes, do not migrate across capillary walls.
Can transform into large multinucleated cells in certain chronic infections.

questions.text: Erythrocytes:

options.text: Are responsible for the major part of blood viscosity.
Contain the enzyme carbonic anhydrase.
Metabolize glucose to produce CO2 and H2O.
Swell to bursting point when suspended in 0.9 per cent (150 mmol/litre) saline.

questions.text: Human plasma albumin:

options.text: Contributes more to plasma colloid osmotic pressure than globulin.
Filters freely at the renal glomerulus.
Is negatively charged at the normal pH of blood.
Carries carbon dioxide in blood.

questions.text: Neutrophil granulocytes:

options.text: Are the most common leukocyte in normal blood.
Contain proteolytic enzymes.
Have a lifespan in the circulation of 3–4 weeks.
Contain actin and myosin microfilaments.

questions.text: Bleeding from a small cut in the skin:

options.text: Is normally diminished by local vascular spasm.
Ceases within about five minutes in normal people.
Is prolonged in severe factor VIII (antihaemophilic globulin) deficiency.
Is greater from warm skin than from cold skin.

questions.text: Antibodies:

options.text: Are protein molecules.
Are absent from the blood in early fetal life.
Are produced at a greater rate after a first, than after a second, exposure to an antigen six weeks later.
Circulating as free immunoglobulins are produced by B lymphocytes.

questions.text: Presynaptic inhibition in the mammalian central nervous system can be mediated by:

options.text: GABA-B receptors on the nerve terminal that increase K⁺ conductance.
GABA-A receptors on the nerve terminal that increase Cl⁻ conductance.
axo-axonic synapses that cause depolarization of the postsynaptic cell.
glycine receptors on the nerve terminal that increase Na⁺ conductance.

questions.text: At the vertebrate neuromuscular junction, the "safety factor" for transmission refers to the fact that:

options.text: the postsynaptic membrane has many more acetylcholine receptors than are needed to generate an end-plate potential.
an action potential in the nerve terminal releases enough acetylcholine to ensure that an action potential is always generated in the muscle fiber.
tetanic stimulation of the nerve leads to a sustained contraction of the muscle.
acetylcholine released from the nerve terminal is rapidly hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: At a typical chemical synapse, the primary factor limiting the maximum rate at which a neuron can transmit information is the:

options.text: time required for the action potential to propagate down the axon.
time required for voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels in the terminal to close.
time required for Ca²⁺ to be cleared from the terminal cytoplasm.
time required for synaptic vesicles to be mobilized, docked, and primed for release.

questions.text: In Myasthenia Gravis, the safety factor for neuromuscular transmission is reduced because:

options.text: antibodies reduce the number of functional acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.
antibodies block the release of acetylcholine from the presynaptic terminal.
antibodies activate acetylcholinesterase, speeding the breakdown of acetylcholine.
antibodies block muscarinic acetylcholine receptors on the muscle fiber.

questions.text: Post-tetanic potentiation (PTP) is a short-term form of synaptic plasticity characterized by:

options.text: a decrease in synaptic strength due to neurotransmitter depletion.
enhanced neurotransmitter release due to accumulation of Ca²⁺ in the presynaptic terminal.
an increase in the number of postsynaptic receptors.
a long-lasting increase in synaptic strength requiring new protein synthesis.

questions.text: A drug that selectively blocks voltage-gated K⁺ channels in a neuron would be expected to:

options.text: hyperpolarize the resting membrane potential.
prevent the generation of the action potential upstroke.
prolong the depolarization phase and duration of the action potential.
block synaptic transmission by preventing Ca²⁺ influx.

questions.text: In a simple spinal reflex arc, stimulation of an inhibitory interneuron making an axo-axonic synapse onto the central terminal of the Ia sensory afferent fiber would result in:

options.text: an action potential in the sensory afferent fiber.
a hyperpolarizing IPSP in the motor neuron.
a depolarizing EPSP in the motor neuron.
no direct change in the membrane potential or firing rate of the motor neuron.

questions.text: A key mechanism of presynaptic inhibition in the mammalian spinal cord involves:

options.text: GABA-B receptor activation increasing K⁺ conductance in the sensory terminal.
activation of metabotropic glutamate receptors on the sensory terminal.
glycine receptor activation increasing Cl⁻ conductance in the motor neuron.
GABA-A receptor activation leading to depolarization (primary afferent depolarization) of the sensory terminal.

questions.text: The haematocrit (packed cell volume):

options.text: May be obtained by centrifugation of blood.
May be calculated by multiplying the mean cell volume by the red cell count.
Rises in a patient who sustains widespread burns.
Rises following injections of aldosterone.

questions.text: Red cell formation is increased:

options.text: By giving vitamin B12 injections to healthy people on a normal diet.
In blood donors one week after a blood donation.
In patients with haemolytic anaemia.
In patients who have a raised blood reticulocyte count.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency may:

options.text: Result from disease of the terminal part of the ileum.
Result in anaemia with small RBCs well filled with haemoglobin.
Cause wasting (atrophy) of the gastric mucosa.
Cause pathological changes in the central nervous system.

questions.text: Coronary blood flow to the left ventricle increases during:

options.text: Early systole.
Myocardial hypoxia.
Hypothermia.
Stimulation of sympathetic nerves to the heart.

questions.text: Local metabolic activity is the chief factor determining the rate of blood flow to the:

options.text: Heart.
Skin.
Skeletal muscle.
Lung.

questions.text: The pressure:

options.text: Drop along large veins is similar to that along large arteries.
Drop across the hepatic portal bed is similar to that across the splenic vascular bed.
In the hepatic portal vein exceeds that in the inferior vena cava.
In foot veins is lower when walking than when standing still.

questions.text: The second heart sound differs from the first heart sound in that it is:

options.text: Related to turbulence set up by valve closure.
Longer lasting than the first sound.
Higher in frequency.
Heard when the ventricles are relaxing.

questions.text: Pulmonary vascular resistance is:

options.text: Less than one-third that offered by the systemic circuit.
Decreased when alveolar oxygen pressure falls.
Expressed in units of volume flow per unit time per unit pressure gradient.
Decreased during exercise.

questions.text: Ventricular filling:

options.text: Depends mainly on atrial contraction.
Begins during isometric ventricular relaxation.
Gives rise to a third heart sound in some healthy people.
Is most rapid in the first half of diastole.

questions.text: Veins:

options.text: Contain most of the blood volume.
Have a sympathetic vasoconstrictor innervation.
Receive nutrition from vasa vasorum arising from their lumen.
Respond to distension by contraction of their smooth muscle.

questions.text: In the heart:

options.text: The left atrial wall is about three times thicker than the right atrial wall.
Systolic contraction normally begins in the left atrium.
Excitation spreads directly from atrial muscle cells to ventricular muscle cells.
The contracting ventricles shorten from apex to base.

questions.text: Isometric (static) exercise differs from isotonic (dynamic) exercise in that it causes a greater increase in:

options.text: Venous return.
Pressure in the veins draining the exercising muscle.
Muscle blood flow.
Mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: The net loss of fluid from capillaries in the legs is increased by:

options.text: Arteriolar dilation.
Change from the recumbent to the standing position.
Lymphatic obstruction.
Plasma albumin depletion.

questions.text: When measuring blood pressure by the auscultatory method:

options.text: The sounds that are heard are generated in the heart.
The cuff pressure at which the first sounds are heard indicate systolic pressure.
The cuff pressure at which the loudest sounds are heard indicate diastolic pressure.
Systolic pressure estimations tend to be lower than those made by the palpatory method.

questions.text: The absolute refractory period in the ventricles:

options.text: Is the period when the ventricles are completely inexcitable.
Corresponds to the period of ventricular depolarization.
Corresponds approximately to the period of ventricular contraction.
Is shorter than the corresponding period in atrial muscle.

questions.text: Vascular resistance:

options.text: Increases by 50 per cent when the vascular radius is halved.
Is related to the thickness of the wall of the vessel.
Is related to the vessel's length.
Is affected by blood viscosity.

questions.text: Sympathetic drive to the heart is increased:

options.text: In exercise.
In excitement.
In hypotension.
When parasympathetic drive is decreased.

questions.text: In an adult subject standing quietly at rest, venous pressure in the:

options.text: Foot is approximately equal to arterial pressure at heart level.
Thorax decreases when the subject inhales.
Hand is subatmospheric when the hand is raised above the head.
Superior vena cava is an index of cardiac filling pressure.

questions.text: Hyperaemia in skeletal muscle during exercise is normally associated with:

options.text: Release of sympathetic vasoconstrictor tone in the exercising muscles.
Capillary dilation due to relaxation of capillary smooth muscle.
A fall in arterial pressure.
An increase in cardiac output.

questions.text: Sinoatrial node cells are:

options.text: Found in both atria.
Innervated by the vagus.
Unable to generate impulses when completely denervated.
Able to generate impulses because their membrane potential is unstable.

questions.text: The first heart sound corresponds in time with:

options.text: Closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves.
The P wave of the electrocardiogram.
A rise in atrial pressure.
A rise in ventricular pressure.

questions.text: Increased sympathetic drive to the heart increases the:

options.text: Rate of diastolic depolarization in sinoatrial node cells.
Coronary blood flow.
Rate of conduction in Purkinje tissue.
Slope of the Frank–Starling (work versus stretch) curve of the heart.

questions.text: The velocity of blood flow:

options.text: In capillaries is low because they offer high resistance to flow.
In veins is greater than in venules.
Can fall to zero in the ascending aorta during diastole.
Is greater towards the centre of large blood vessels than at the periphery.

questions.text: The strength of contraction of left ventricular muscle increases when:

options.text: End-diastolic ventricular filling pressure rises.
Serum potassium levels rise.
Blood calcium levels fall.
Strenuous exercise is undertaken.

questions.text: During isometric ventricular contraction:

options.text: The entry and exit valves of the ventricle are closed.
Pressure in the aorta rises.
Pressure in the atria falls.
Left coronary blood flow falls.

questions.text: In the electrocardiogram, the:

options.text: QRS complex follows the onset of ventricular contraction.
T wave is due to repolarization of the ventricles.
PR interval corresponds with atrial depolarization.
RT interval is related to ventricular action potential duration.

questions.text: Cardiac output:

options.text: Is normally expressed as the output of one ventricle in litres/minute.
May not increase when heart rate rises.
Usually rises when a person lies down.
Rises in a hot environment.

questions.text: Arterioles:

options.text: Have a smaller wall:lumen ratio than have arteries.
Play a major role in regulating arterial blood pressure.
Play a major role in regulating local blood flow.
Offer more resistance to flow than capillaries.

questions.text: The Purkinje tissue cells in the heart:

options.text: Conduct impulses faster than some neurones.
Are larger than ventricular myocardial cells.
Lead to contraction of the base before the apex of the heart.
Are responsible for the short duration of the QRS complex.

questions.text: In the brachial artery:

options.text: Pulse waves travel at the same velocity as blood.
Pulse pressure falls with decreasing elasticity of the wall.
Pressure rises markedly when the artery is occluded distally.
Pressure falls when the arm is raised above head level.

questions.text: The tendency for blood flow to be turbulent increases when there is a decrease in blood:

options.text: Vessel diameter.
Density.
Flow velocity.
Viscosity.

questions.text: Arterioles offer more resistance to flow than other vessels since they have:

options.text: Thicker muscular walls.
Richer sympathetic innervation.
Smaller internal diameters.
A smaller total cross-sectional area.

questions.text: In the denervated heart, left ventricular stroke work increases when:

options.text: The end-diastolic length of the ventricular fibres increases.
Peripheral resistance rises.
Blood volume falls.
Right ventricular output increases.

questions.text: Systemic hypertension may be caused by:

options.text: Hypoxia due to chronic respiratory failure.
Excessive secretion of aldosterone.
Excessive secretion of adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).
Myocardial thickening (hypertrophy) of the left ventricle.

questions.text: Peripheral differs from central circulatory failure in that:

options.text: Hypovolaemia is unusual.
It leads to underperfusion of the tissues.
Cardiac output is usually normal.
Ventricular function is usually normal.

questions.text: In atrial fibrillation:

options.text: The electrocardiogram shows no evidence of atrial activity.
Ventricular rate is lower than atrial rate.
Respiratory sinus arrhythmia can usually be seen.
The ventricular rate is irregular.

questions.text: Severe systemic hypertension may result in:

options.text: An increase in the number of myocardial cells in the left ventricle.
Increased QRS voltage in certain leads.
Increased coronary blood flow.
Impaired vision.

questions.text: Auscultation of the heart can provide evidence of:

options.text: The direction of turbulent flow causing a murmur.
Aortic stenosis, if there is a loud pre-systolic murmur in the aortic valve area.
Mitral incompetence, if a systolic murmur is heard in the axilla.
Ventricular septal defect, if a loud diastolic murmur is heard.

questions.text: The electrocardiogram shows:

options.text: Irregular P waves in atrial flutter.
Regular QRS complexes in atrial fibrillation.
Regular QRS complexes in complete heart block.
High voltage R waves over the right ventricle in right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: The jugular venous:

options.text: Pulse is not visible in normal healthy people.
Pulse has greater amplitude in patients with tricuspid incompetence.
Pulse can vary widely in amplitude in patients with complete heart block.
Pressure is raised in patients with right ventricular failure.

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, isovolumetric ventricular contraction:

options.text: Begins with the closure of the semilunar valves.
Occurs while all four cardiac valves are open.
Ends with the opening of the atrioventricular valves.
Is the phase when ventricular volume remains constant.

questions.text: The phase of rapid ventricular filling in early diastole:

options.text: Contributes the majority of the ventricular end-diastolic volume.
Is caused primarily by atrial contraction.
Is associated with the fourth heart sound (S4).
Is absent in patients with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: The second heart sound (S2) is primarily caused by:

options.text: Closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves.
Turbulent blood flow into the ventricles.
Closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves.
Atrial contraction against a non-compliant ventricle.

questions.text: The pacemaker potential in SA nodal cells is primarily due to:

options.text: A progressive decrease in potassium efflux.
A steady influx of calcium through L-type channels.
The "funny current" (I_f), a slow inward Na⁺ current activated by hyperpolarization.
Rapid depolarization caused by fast sodium channels.

questions.text: The action potential in ventricular myocardial cells, compared to SA node cells, is characterized by:

options.text: A stable resting membrane potential near -90 mV.
Phase 4 spontaneous depolarization.
A slower upstroke (phase 0) mediated by L-type calcium channels.
The absence of a distinct plateau phase (phase 2).

questions.text: The slowest conduction velocity in the cardiac conduction system is found in the:

options.text: SA node.
Atrial muscle.
AV node.
Bundle of His.

questions.text: The intrinsic rate of depolarization (automaticity) is highest in the:

options.text: Purkinje fibers.
Bundle of His.
AV node.
SA node.

questions.text: The plateau phase (Phase 2) of the ventricular action potential is critical for:

options.text: Ensuring rapid conduction through the Purkinje network.
Preventing tetanic contraction of cardiac muscle.
Allowing time for atrial contraction to complete.
Generating the QRS complex on the ECG.

questions.text: The primary ionic event responsible for the upstroke (Phase 0) in Purkinje fiber action potentials is:

options.text: Influx of calcium through L-type channels.
Efflux of potassium.
Influx of sodium through fast voltage-gated channels.
Inactivation of the funny current (I_f).

questions.text: Platelets are directly activated by:

options.text: Exposure to prostacyclin (PGI2) from endothelial cells.
Binding to von Willebrand Factor (vWF) exposed at sites of vascular injury.
High levels of circulating nitric oxide (NO).
The presence of heparin in plasma.

questions.text: In the coagulation cascade, the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways converge to activate:

options.text: Factor VII.
Factor X.
Prothrombin (Factor II).
Fibrinogen (Factor I).

questions.text: The primary role of Vitamin K in coagulation is to:

options.text: Activate platelets.
Serve as a cofactor for thrombin.
Catalyze the cross-linking of fibrin.
Promote the hepatic gamma-carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, and X.

questions.text: Heparin's main anticoagulant mechanism is:

options.text: Direct inhibition of thrombin (Factor IIa).
Inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase.
Binding to and potentiating the activity of antithrombin III.
Degradation of fibrin polymer.

questions.text: Warfarin exerts its anticoagulant effect by:

options.text: Chelating calcium ions in plasma.
Directly inhibiting the formation of the prothrombinase complex.
Inhibiting the vitamin K-dependent gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors.
Stimulating the release of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA).

questions.text: The initial electrical vector of ventricular depolarization (septal activation) proceeds:

options.text: From the apex to the base of the heart.
From the left ventricle to the right ventricle.
From the endocardium to the epicardium.
From the right ventricle to the left ventricle and from left to right across the septum.

questions.text: The mean electrical axis of the QRS complex in the frontal plane is normally:

options.text: Between -30° and -90° (left axis deviation).
Between -30° and +90°.
Between +90° and +180° (right axis deviation).
Between 0° and -30°.

questions.text: Lead aVR in the standard ECG:

options.text: Views the heart from the left lateral perspective.
Has a positive electrode on the left arm.
Normally shows a predominantly negative QRS complex.
Is used to assess inferior wall pathology.

questions.text: Which chest lead (precordial lead) is positioned at the 4th intercostal space at the right sternal border?

options.text: V1
V2
V3
V4

questions.text: The augmented limb leads (aVL, aVR, aVF):

options.text: Are bipolar leads.
Require a central terminal as a reference point.
Record the potential difference between two limbs.
Have smaller amplitude signals than the standard limb leads.

questions.text: A normal sinus rhythm on an ECG is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:

options.text: A regular R-R interval.
A P wave before every QRS complex.
A constant PR interval between 0.12 and 0.20 seconds.
A variable P wave morphology.

questions.text: On an ECG, the PR interval represents the time from:

options.text: The start of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization.
The peak of the P wave to the peak of the R wave.
The end of atrial repolarization to the start of ventricular repolarization.
Ventricular depolarization to ventricular repolarization.

questions.text: If an ECG rhythm strip shows 25 small squares (1 mm each) between two consecutive R waves, the heart rate is approximately:

options.text: 60 beats per minute.
75 beats per minute.
100 beats per minute.
150 beats per minute.

questions.text: The "rule of 300" for rapid heart rate estimation on an ECG uses:

options.text: The number of QRS complexes in a 10-second strip.
The number of large squares (5 mm) between two R waves.
The number of small squares (1 mm) between two R waves.
The duration of the QT interval.

questions.text: The QT interval on an ECG:

options.text: Should be constant regardless of heart rate.
Represents total ventricular activity (depolarization and repolarization).
Is measured from the end of the P wave to the end of the T wave.
Normally shortens with bradycardia.

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, the point at which ventricular pressure exceeds aortic pressure corresponds to:

options.text: The onset of isovolumetric relaxation.
The opening of the aortic valve.
The peak of the 'v' wave in the atrial pressure trace.
The onset of the P wave on ECG.

questions.text: Atrial contraction (atrial systole):

options.text: Is essential for ventricular filling in a healthy heart at rest.
Contributes the "a wave" to the jugular venous pulse.
Occurs during the QRS complex on the ECG.
Is represented by the T wave on the ECG.

questions.text: The primary determinant of coronary blood flow is:

options.text: Sympathetic vasoconstrictor tone.
Aortic diastolic pressure.
Myocardial metabolic demand (local tissue oxygenation).
Parasympathetic (vagal) activity.

questions.text: The PR segment on an ECG (the isoelectric line after the P wave) corresponds to:

options.text: Atrial repolarization.
Conduction delay through the AV node.
Ventricular depolarization.
The rapid ventricular filling phase.

questions.text: The U wave on an ECG, when present, is thought to possibly represent:

options.text: Atrial repolarization.
Delayed repolarization of the Purkinje fibers.
Early ventricular depolarization.
An artifact of movement.

questions.text: In the coagulation cascade, Factor XIII (Fibrin stabilizing factor):

options.text: Converts prothrombin to thrombin.
Converts fibrinogen to soluble fibrin monomers.
Cross-links fibrin polymers to form a stable clot.
Activates Factor X in the common pathway.

questions.text: Tissue Factor (Factor III) is the primary initiator of:

options.text: The intrinsic pathway.
The common pathway.
The fibrinolytic pathway.
The extrinsic pathway.

questions.text: The endothelium produces which of the following potent inhibitors of platelet aggregation?

options.text: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2)
Adenosine Diphosphate (ADP)
Prostacyclin (PGI2) and Nitric Oxide (NO)
Von Willebrand Factor (vWF)

questions.text: Protein C, along with its cofactor Protein S, exerts an anticoagulant effect by:

options.text: Directly inhibiting Factor Xa.
Inactivating Factors Va and VIIIa.
Enhancing plasminogen activation.
Blocking tissue factor.

questions.text: The primary physiological trigger for the release of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is:

options.text: A fall in blood pressure.
The presence of thrombin.
Vascular injury and fibrin formation.
An increase in platelet count.

questions.text: The vector of the final phase of ventricular depolarization is directed toward the:

options.text: Right shoulder.
Left leg.
Left ventricle (lateral wall) and base.
Right ventricle.

questions.text: Left Axis Deviation (LAD) on the ECG is most commonly associated with:

options.text: Normal variant in tall, thin individuals.
Left ventricular hypertrophy.
Right ventricular hypertrophy.
Acute pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Which bipolar limb lead has its positive electrode on the left leg and negative electrode on the left arm?

options.text: Lead I
Lead II
Lead III
Lead aVF

questions.text: The chest lead V4 is typically placed:

options.text: 4th intercostal space, left sternal border.
5th intercostal space, midclavicular line.
5th intercostal space, anterior axillary line.
4th intercostal space, right sternal border.

questions.text: In a regular rhythm, if the R-R interval spans 4 large squares on ECG paper (25 mm/s), the heart rate is:

options.text: 60 bpm
75 bpm
100 bpm
150 bpm

questions.text: The absolute refractory period of ventricular muscle corresponds approximately to which parts of the ECG?

options.text: The entire QT interval.
From the start of the QRS to the peak of the T wave.
The PR interval.
The TP segment.

questions.text: Phase 1 (initial repolarization) of the ventricular action potential is due to:

options.text: Inactivation of fast Na⁺ channels and a transient outward K⁺ current (I_to).
Influx of calcium through L-type channels.
Activation of the funny current (I_f).
Sustained influx of sodium.

questions.text: The long refractory period in cardiac muscle is primarily a function of:

options.text: The slow conduction through the AV node.
The plateau phase (Phase 2) of the action potential.
The high resting membrane potential.
The speed of the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a function of platelets?

options.text: Adhesion to exposed collagen via vWF.
Aggregation via fibrinogen bridges between GP IIb/IIIa receptors.
Synthesis and release of coagulation factors like prothrombin.
Release of granules containing ADP, serotonin, and thromboxane A2.

questions.text: The activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) test primarily evaluates the function of:

options.text: The extrinsic and common pathways.
The intrinsic and common pathways.
Platelet function.
Fibrinolysis.

questions.text: The Prothrombin Time (PT) test primarily evaluates the function of:

options.text: The extrinsic and common pathways.
The intrinsic and common pathways.
Platelet function.
Fibrinolysis.

questions.text: Thrombin's (Factor IIa) actions include all EXCEPT:

options.text: Converting fibrinogen to fibrin.
Activating platelets.
Activating Factor XIII.
Activating Protein C (when bound to thrombomodulin).
Directly lysing (breaking down) fibrin clot.

questions.text: In the context of the conduction system, the bundle branches are located:

options.text: Within the interatrial septum.
In the wall of the right atrium.
In the upper part of the interventricular septum.
Throughout the ventricular free walls.

questions.text: An ECG shows a rhythm with no discernible P waves, an irregularly irregular ventricular response, and narrow QRS complexes. This is most consistent with:

options.text: Sinus arrhythmia.
Atrial flutter.
Atrial fibrillation.
Ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Which ECG finding is characteristic of hyperkalemia?

options.text: Shortened QT interval.
Peaked (tented) T waves.
Prominent U waves.
Prolonged PR interval.

questions.text: Prominent U waves on an ECG are most classically associated with:

options.text: Hypercalcemia.
Hypokalemia.
Hypernatremia.
Hypomagnesemia.

questions.text: The "J point" on an ECG is defined as:

options.text: The peak of the R wave.
The point where the QRS complex ends and the ST segment begins.
The onset of the P wave.
The end of the T wave.

questions.text: The primary source of energy for platelet activation and aggregation is derived from:

options.text: Fatty acid oxidation.
Glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation.
The pentose phosphate pathway.
Anaerobic metabolism only.

questions.text: Plasmin is the key enzyme of the fibrinolytic system. Its primary action is to:

options.text: Activate Factor X.
Degrade fibrin and fibrinogen.
Inhibit thrombin.
Activate platelets.

questions.text: A patient has a prolonged bleeding time but normal PT and aPTT. The most likely defect is in:

options.text: The intrinsic coagulation pathway.
The extrinsic coagulation pathway.
The common coagulation pathway.
Platelet function or number.

questions.text: The "systolic click" heard on auscultation is often associated with:

options.text: Aortic stenosis.
Mitral valve prolapse.
Atrial septal defect.
Ventricular septal defect.

questions.text: The fourth heart sound (S4):

options.text: Is a normal finding in children and young adults.
Is associated with atrial contraction against a stiff, non-compliant ventricle.
Occurs just after the first heart sound (S1).
Is best heard at the base of the heart (aortic area).

questions.text: During expiration, the splitting of the second heart sound (S2):

options.text: Becomes wider.
Disappears or becomes narrow.
Is unrelated to respiration.
Is caused by delayed aortic valve closure.

questions.text: The "c wave" in the atrial pressure tracing is caused by:

options.text: Atrial contraction.
Ventricular contraction causing bulging of the AV valves into the atria.
Passive filling of the atria from the veins.
Opening of the semilunar valves.

questions.text: The "x descent" in the atrial pressure tracing is primarily due to:

options.text: Atrial relaxation.
Downward movement of the ventricular base during systole.
Atrial filling.
The onset of ventricular diastole.

questions.text: The most common cause of right axis deviation on the ECG is:

options.text: Left ventricular hypertrophy.
Right ventricular hypertrophy.
